Not well explained in my opinion. I’m just trying to piece this together. There’s stimulated absorption, spontaneous emission, and stimulated emission. Let’s say that we start with a row of 3 hydrogen atoms, all with electrons in excited states due to stimulated absorption. By my understanding, the first atom’s electron will drop down to its meta state and then emit a photon, ultimately dropping down to its ground state. This emitted photon will go to the next hydrogen atom who’s electron is sitting at the meta state level. Once this photon reaches that electron, it will cause stimulated emission whereby that electron will immediately drop down to the ground state and simultaneously release a photon. The reason for these spontaneous emissions and stimulated emissions is due to quantum mechanics. The air we breathe has ten septillion atoms per centimetre cubed, the best laboratory vacuums on earth maybe around 10 billion per centimetre cubed, interplanetaryspace at 10 million per, interstellar space at maybe a couple thousand per 10 cubic centimetres, and intergalactic space where a cube with 200,000km dimensions has the same amount of atoms as the air that occupies your refrigerator. There’s a lot more particles that we don’t know about though called virtual particles that pop in and out of existence. These excited states are extremely unstable, so it’s theorized that virtual particles poppingin and out of existence cause electrons to fall back down. We also know that particles prefer to exist in a state that consumes the least amount of energy.  Now 2 photons are around. Then these photons will travel to the third hydrogen atom. Since some time has passed its likely that the electron in the third atom will have dropped down to its ground state before the 2 fore-mentioned photons arrive to relieve it of its photon. This means the third atom will spontaneously emit a photon, usually in a random direction, not the same direction as the 2 other photons in motion. This process happens over and over until there is a build up of photons - some of which can be emitted through the partial mirror. This is my basic understanding of it.

The fact that this impressively incorrect video is still up is a travesty. Bravo for explaining Bosonic exchange in an easy to understand way, but that has absolutely nothing to do with stimulated emission. Hence why your phone flashlight doesn't randomly turn into a laser, and why the coherence you get from them are much, much higher than this argument implies.


As for how it actually works, when an electron is in an excited state, it can "absorb" a photon that matches the energy of an electronic transition from a lower energy state to the current energy state, and it when it does that it spits out two photons which are identical to the "absorbed" photon. This is stimulated emission, and because it turns 1 photon into 2 photons, you can use it to amplify light. You do this by first finding a material that can feasibly achieve a population inversion (more electrons in excited states than the ground state) and a couple of other desirable properties that are too technical for a youtube comment. Slap two highly reflecting mirrors around that material to speed up the stimulated emission (more photons=more likely for a photon to "absorb"=more stimulated emission=more photons=... ad nauseum). Congratulations, you have a laser. There are more things you can do to increase the quality of the laser/some important technical details are ignored, but that's the gist of it. "Absorb" was in quotation marks throughout this because it's not technically absorption, but thinking of it as absorption followed by emission of two photons is so close to what's happening that basically all laser people think of it like that in real life.

If you do an actual quantum field theoretical calculation, it turns out that the probability of an atom in an excited state decaying to some lower state by emitting a photon having the same momentum and polarization as n photons in the background is proportional to (n+1). Thus more photons emitted with the same momentum and polarization, means more photons with same momentum and polarization in the background now and probability is again increased, and this keeps on going. When n=0 (no photons in the background), it turns out that an excited state of an atom interact with the vacuum itself which leads to it's decay to a lower state. This is the phenomenon of spontaneous emission, as opposed to the previous process which was stimulated emission. So to truly keep an atom in an excited state without decay, you'd either need to remove the vacuum itself or somehow fill up all the lower energy levels.

Explaining what photons do is not the same as explaining why they do what they do.  For example, in showing that there is a greater probability of finding photons in the same "state," (at 00:50) you still don't yet have any rationale for giving a "Therefore...."  This probability has nothing to do with why photons from the output of a good laser are in phase.  Laser designers don't say, "The light will probably be in phase."

Certainly you'd agree that their design specifications have something to do with it.  If the specifications are more relevant than probabilities, why not include them in a "How lasers work" video if the intention is to show how lasers work?

It may be worth your while, also, in studying why the theoretical physicists some years ago said laser light wasn't possible, and how they treated the people who said it was.  Some of the speculations in modern physics have to be let go, it seems to me, considering the fact that laser light is obviously possible.

Not every material can be made into a laser. It isn't enough just to pump a bunch of energy into a substance. If you pump a bunch of energy into a solid, you won't get a laser beam. You will get a glowing, hot material that emits incoherent light across a broad spectrum (that is, white light). For a laser to work, the active medium must be able to absorb and store the photon. That is, the medium must have a fluorescent state. The wavelength at which the laser will produce laser light depends on the energy of the fluorescent state of the active medium.

Light (photons) are indistinguishable Quantum Mechanical bosons that follow Bose-Einstein statistics.

Normally the possible states would be: up/up, up/dn, dn/up, and dn/dn

But since the particles are indistinguishable in a fundamental quantum way the possiblities: up/dn and dn/up are identical.

The states are actually: up/up. dn/dn, and updn/updn a superposition like the Schrodinger cat that is both dead and alive.

Finally:
8) This "attractive" force that tends to line up bosons states is the same concept that causes super-conducting, super-fluid, and Einstein-Bose condensates. 
9) The photons will bounce back and forth a few times stimulating the emission of more and more coherent nearly identical photons before quantum tunnneling out of the "weaker" mirror.
10) The emitted photons are so alike that their superposition enhances the beam's particle like properties forming localized "wave-packets."

Continued:
6) The photons that bounce back and forth carry energy that disturbs the excited atoms between the two mirrors. This disturbance provides the slight push necessary for the atoms to drop to ground state. Exactly like tapping a house of cards and letting them all fall down.
7) Now fermions repel via the Pauli E. principle conversely bosons (like light) attract meaning that the stimulated photons are more than likely going to be similar (coherent) to the stimualating photons.

This will explain it:

1) Energy is put into the LASER - into what is called the "lasing material.

2) Just like a light bulb or anyother object that obsorbs energy the atoms get into an excited state.

3) Then some of these atoms will spontaneously drop back to ground state.

4) They release light with the equivalent energy/frequency of the drop.

5) Nearly all of the photons are re-obsorbed except for those that hit the fully reflecting mirror on one side or the mostly reflecting on the other.

1) The second photon's energy did exist as energy stored in the excited atom.

2) Photons follow energy conservation even though photons don't have mass

3) Photons do have a boson to boson attractive "force" that tends to naturally unify or line up photons. This force is identical in origin to the repulsive Pauli Exclusion principle for fermions that repel identical fermions trying to be in the same state.

4) The closer bosons are to being in the same state the stronger the "force"

Photons are pure energy released from the electromagnetic field. Atoms don't contain photons like bullets in a magazine. Any release in energy produces one photon (or an entangled pair...) with its energy proportional to the photon's frequency.

If you keep exciting atoms (adding energy) and they keep getting "tapped" (stimulated) by photons to release their energy you can keep releasing photons indefinitely.

A laser is just like a normal light in that you can't see the photons until they reach your eyes. Thus, the only place which bears evidence of the laser beam is matter being struck by that laser beam and bouncing those photons to your eyes.

Exciting the medium causes energy to be put into it. This energy is then released some way. Photons are the most common way for matter to lose excess energy. If you stop putting energy into it, it'll eventually stop emitting photons.

Common cheap lasers use a rod made of ruby (corundum) as a medium, with an electromagnetic coil wrapped around the rod. The closer fermions like electrons, protons, or neutrons are the more they repel due to the minus sign.

The closer bosons like light (photons) are the more they attracted and want to be in the same state because of the + sign.

Lasers just bounce the same loght back and fourth over the same spot long enough for the light to naturally unite. 

When a whole bunch of waves unite you get particle like properties and this is why a laser looks like a beam of particles.

a(1)*b(2) + or - b(1)*a(2) = state of two identical particles 
+ is for bosons,    - is for fermions

If there is any room for another electron in a lower energy state around an atom, an electron in a higher energy state will release a photon to reach that lower energy state (it's a bit more complicated than that, but that's the main idea). So, it's not really possible to "hold" an electron in a higher energy state than it "wants" to be in. 

Also, As you go to higher an higher energy levels, the differences between the levels becomes exponentially smaller, so there is a limit on the energy.
